tools.name: create-event
tools.title: Create Event
tools.description: Creates a new event in the user's Google Calendar

title.description:
The title/summary of the calendar event

@example "Team Weekly Sync" or "Meeting with John"

query.description:
Search query to find matching contacts

@description Text to search for in contact names and email addresses. The search matches from the beginning
of words (prefix matching). For example:
- "john" matches "John Smith" or "Johnson"
- "sm" matches "Smith" or "Smart"
- "jo sm" matches "John Smith"
@example "john" - Find contacts with names starting with "John"
"sm" - Find contacts with names containing words starting with "Sm"
@constraints - Must be non-empty string
- Matches are case-insensitive
- Partial word matches only work from the start of words

tools.name: delete-event
tools.title: Delete Event
tools.description: Deletes an event from the user's Google Calendar

eventId.description: The ID of the event to delete.

tools.name: edit-event
tools.title: Edit Event
tools.description: Edits an existing event in the user's Google Calendar

eventId.description: The ID of the event to edit

duration.description: The duration of the event in minutes

attendees.description: The email addresses of the attendees of the event

conferencingProvider.description: The conferencing provider of the event

tools.name: search-events
tools.title: Search Events
tools.description: Searches events from the user's Google Calendar

query.description:
Free text search terms to find events

@example When user asks "find my 1:1 with Beth", use query "beth" to find meetings where Beth is an attendee
@example When user asks "show my team meetings", use query "team" to find relevant meetings
@remarks - Focus on key identifying terms rather than guessing exact meeting titles
- For 1:1s or meetings with specific people, search for the person's name only
- For topic-based searches, use key topic words (e.g. "standup", "planning", "review")

Searches across these calendar event fields:
- summary/title
- description
- location
- attendee's displayName and email
- organizer's displayName and email

tools.name: check-availability
tools.title: Check Availability
tools.description: Checks the availability of potential attendees for a given time period
tools.instructions: Automatically includes the current user in the list of attendees.

tools.name: get-current-user
tools.title: Get Current User
tools.description: Returns information about the currently authenticated user

tools.name: get-current-time
tools.title: Get Current Time
tools.description: Returns the current time of the user in the user's timezone
tools.instructions:
Get the current time

@remarks Use this tool only if you need to get the current time.
Returns the current time in ISO 8601 format with timezone offset (e.g., "2024-06-15T14:30:00-07:00"),
which is the recommended format for accurate timezone handling with LLMs.
The timezone offset (e.g., -07:00, +02:00) is explicitly included rather than using Z (UTC)
to ensure proper timezone interpretation.

preferences.name: defaultEventDuration
preferences.title: Default Event Duration
preferences.description: The default duration for new events

scripts.prepublishOnly:
echo "

It seems like you are trying to publish the Raycast extension to npm.

If you did intend to publish it to npm, remove the \`prepublishOnly\` script and rerun \`npm publish\` again.
If you wanted to publish it to the Raycast Store instead, use \`npm run publish\` instead.

" && exit 1

ai.instructions:
Include a link to the event in your response to make it easier for the user to view it.
If no email domain is provided for other attendees, call the `get-current-user` tool and prefer attendees from the same domain as the current user.
Try to call the `search-contacts` tool in parallel when possible.
Call the `get-current-time` tool if you need to know the current time, e.g. when creating an event within a relative time frame like "today in 1h".
If no attendees are provided, just create the event, it will be private.
